bibl.note: This is a letter dated August 25, 1818 from Ann Eliza King to her cousin James Moore King. She wrote to tell him of a lady she has found for him to possibly marry. In the letter she offers a detailed description of the young lady, and laments about James' wasted bachelor life.

div1.p: When I last wrote you I immagined it wuld be the last time for I was certain you have married and would of course neglect your correspondent I learn by your letter that you are still unmarried certainly you would not put me to the trouble to find you a fin girl that I think would sute you and not eaven come to take a peep at her I have searched jonsonSampson Duplin Harover Cumberland and quite to Onslow and to my utter mortification could not find one that I think would sute you I have since explored Wayne County and think I have found her I will give you a description of her and if you like it you must let me no and I will try to intercede for you Of wealth I will say nothing. for that of course is not an object with with you Now for her person

She is foot high; compact, blue eyes; dark hair; round face; tolerable thin lips, white teath , very even; quite a pleasant countinance ; small foot and hand; and a very handsome brown skin has a cosidderable shean of good sence
dances admirably and leavs acquaintance better than any girl I allmost even saw She has a great number of admirers and if you do not wish her spoiled with flattery make a hurry.

I imagin to myself that I see you seated in on corner of Batchelors Hall poring over some old moldy Book or sitting with your eye fixed on vacency or with your hed on your hand making marks with your cain and talking noncence for the want of a wife to talk it for you. You no enough of the women to no they are never out of idle chat and changes the subject of conversation as often as a nightingale does its notes
You do not no how it would grace your Courner to have a handsome wife in it and not stay there yourself like an Old Rat in a dory as some others of our relatives have.

What news I have is not very pleasant and therefore will refer it untill I see you which I am in hopes will be very soon. You desired me to let you no something of your friends here your relations the Moores are all in good health Uncle Henry and Nathan Kings family have had some sickness
lattenly but have recovered the rest of your relations are generally well Mother is in a very low state of health and we expect to leave here in a few days for the Bladen Springs Cousin Ann Maria Rhodes is married to Coln Ward of Onslow I had the honor to be bridesmaid and the pleasure of quite a pleasant trip
Cousin King was marr few weeks ago to mr Bryand
My letter insensibly grown long I am actually ashamed of except Dear Cousin my cince and ardent for your

closer.add: P.S. I have with regrete to you of death of aunt Hamy Hamy King yours &c A,, King
Deaths of aunt Hamy King she must the wife of Nathan or John
